name: solidago
country-or-region-of-origin: North America, Mexico, South America, and Eurasia
wildlife-value: Birds eat the plant's seed. This plant supports Wavy-lined Emerald (Synchlora aerata) larvae.  It also attracts butterflies, bees, and wasps. The genus Solidago supports the following specialized bees: Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) asteris, Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) braccata, Andrena (Cnemidandrena) hirticincta, Andrena (Cnemidandrena) nubecula, Andrena (Callandrena s.l.) simplex, Perdita (Perdita) octomaculata, Melissodes (Eumelissodes) fumosus, Colletes simulans, and Colletes solidaginis.
edibility: Young leaves are edible. The plant is also used to make herbal teas.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
flower-description: Blooms July through October with tiny, bright yellow flowers in dense, erect, club-shaped terminal clusters.
leaf-description: In the upper half of the plant, there are often small leaves that develop from the upper axils of the primary leaves; they have a wing-like appearance. In some species, the basal leaves are shed before flowering.
stem-description: Stiff, narrow-leaved, stems typically growing 2-3' tall supporting terminal flower clusters.
uses: Native Americans used goldenrod for medicinal purposes. They made tea to reduce fever. They used it as a poultice for bee stings.  Some chewed the flowers to treat sore throats.
